setup.question: Why did the narrator's wife react the way she did when she got home to see workmen at the house?
answers: She was upset that it seemed like the narrator was giving up on his work by tearing down his laboratory space
He had shown no sign of actually reporting on his work, and she didn't know what this change meant

Text.text:
The narrator is passionate and secretive about his work. The story starts with him in the lab, interrupted by his daughter. He blocks his daughter's view. After the wife comes to call him to lunch 
and

But despite his eccentricity, his wife loves him just the same [I'll back with quotes if B attempts to refute]. It can be concluded that the wife supports his work and wishes for his success. So of course, when she came home from a trip she
It upset her that the lab was gone. It meant her husband had given up working
The narrator is a scientist who is working on an experiment to create
, animal-like
. The issue is that he is keeping this entire experiment as well as his lab /completely/ hidden from his family. An example of this is when she calls him for lunch, as she
and

. (I can provide more ev)

Later, when he releases the volplas he gets workmen to come to the house, and when his wife returns he says
to which his wife says
. This also proves that the wife didn't know whether he was going to write a paper.

I don't get option B or debater B's reasoning. What's the relation between *not* reporting work & tearing down lab?

Open quotes tab I'll fill in gaps:

. So the whole thing about reporting work is just in response to what he says about why he's tearing the lab down. It's part of the conversation but is kinda a misquote since it's not the initial primary concern behind the wife's reaction when seeing the lab being torn down. We've both agreed that the scientist is secretive so the wife probably didn't know what to expect in terms of publications of his research way before the change of the lab

My narrative fits: tearing down secret lab = upset giving up

Obviously she knows that he's not giving up on his work because he literally tells her that he is continuing the work but just doesn't need the laboratory anymore. The difference is that now he mentions that he is planning on writing a report about the work which he had never mentioned before to his wife because of how he kept her in the dark about the whole experiment. As such, she doesn't really know how to act because of her lack of information and him just now telling her that he plans on reporting the work.

.... now B is just confusing the judge about something B themself quoted. See opening speech, /I've finished my work/ (6692-6697). Clarify: I agree that wife didn't know whether or not he was writing a report, continuation of what wife is saying

, as in he never published before. But I disagree that this is relevant to the question. The question is about the wife's reaction of the lab being teared down... if wife never knew about the research/work, how would she know whether ... writing the report is contingent on the lab still existing?

What the wife is more likely to initially feel at seeing the lab being tearing down is *upset* because it is the one lab the person she loves has been doing secret work in.

The wife comes home, sees the narrator there with the crew, and asks him! It's that simple. A has never provided any ev that the wife immediately jumped to the conclusion that he was tearing it all down because why would he given he had been working on this for close to a decade at this point. I have ev that the wife doesn't really know much about what the scientist is working on, which means she would be questioning him, as well as ev that he has never actually reported work before, which leads to her asking him.

I didn't think B made a strong argument but I think it's the right answer. A is clearly a very skilled debater but I think what is missing is that the key quote from A c.6659-6688 is ambiguous and I don't think there is evidence that she is necessarily upset. I think A argues that it is "likely" that the wife is upset, but given how skilled A is, I think they would have better evidence if this was the correct answer.
tbh have no clue - have a little preference for A but that is all

tbh I didnt learn too much from this, however I dont think he gave up working just because of the fact that he announces that hes going to write a paper about his work - so with that in mind if the lab is truly gone then it means that he wasnt giving up but that his work had been completed

I think im still convinced of B but not entirely, I dont think each side has that much evidence to add so with that I'll vote for B just on the basis that their "published research" quote makes sense with the story.

answers.reason for outcome: I had to use a little bit of my own reasoning here, based off of the quotes, since the research was about to be published I knew that he wasnt giving up so that was my first clue, and then her reaction to him telling her that is her looking at him appraisingly which roughly translates to judgement and evaluation. so based off of those clues I was able to deduce that she was unsure on what this change meant. I gave a lower judge rating than normal just because I was a little skeptical of both sides, and A sounded very confident.

I didn't think B made a strong argument but I think it's the right answer. A is clearly a very skilled debater but I think what is missing is that the key quote from A c.6659-6688 is ambiguous and I don't think there is evidence that she is necessarily upset. I think A argues that it is "likely" that the wife is upset, but given how skilled A is, I think they would have better evidence if this was the correct answer.
